segments.text: Yeah, or you can hear it here, you know.
But what I love is that you can go two hours.
So we're recording now.
Okay, well, what's Barry Moses?
My library.
I love it.
Oh, I would just take a walk through it.
Those are my books.
That section there.
My books, the books.
The books that I've done in a lifetime.
Do you have a number?
Or is it a about number?
Do you know?
It's an about number.
About 230.
Wow.
Now, that includes the books that I have.
designed without illustrations.
That includes books that have jackets that I've done illustrations for it, books that I've done just a frontispiece for.
And it includes books that I've thoroughly illustrated.
In other words, basically books that I've had a hand in.
One way or the other.
I like that.
And these are my rare and fine first editions.
Your collection?
Yeah.
Can you briefly describe it to me?
The collection?
It's very eclectic.
An eclectic collection.
Which I think in many ways is the best kind.
I mean, it's just the things that interest me.
A lot of these books are written by people who are friends of mine.
There's some real good friends of mine, like Tracy Kidder and Bob Fagels and Mariani and so forth.
But a lot of them are people that I have.
Kay Gibbons, who's one of my best buddies.
I love Kay.
and Ann Patchett.
You know how to work?
Yeah, I like this one too.
I like the last one too.
I was just reading the other day the thing about heritage books.
And then there's some rare books.
There are, you know, Derrydale Press and there's this almost complete collection of Rockwell Kent and there are
Other things, I have a first edition of the Robert Bridegroom that Eudora Welty signed to me and all that kind of stuff.
I have a first edition of Huckleberry Finn.
Oh, that's nice.
Yeah, I got that stuff.
But there's no focus.
The only focus is that it interests me.
There you go.
Or that it's been done by friends of mine, people that I know.
What are the dogs' names again?
The big English Mastiff is Truman.
English Mastiff, yeah.
He's named after Harry S. Truman.
The small English manuscript is Ike, named after Dwight.
We go in presidential succession.
We started with Woodrow Wilson, and then we had Roosevelt, and then D.J.
And then, those are my only two dogs, the Roddy's Ball.
So anyway, that's what that all is.
And then down here, we begin doing other children's.
Down here, my grandmother would sit on the floor and read.
And then, unnatural history over here, being mythology and religion.
My medical shelf, our shelves.
I kind of sort of collect medical books that have photographs in them.
Photographs?
I'm not interested in medical illustration as such, but I am interested in photography of anomalies and all that sort of thing.
What kind of wood?
Cherry.
Cherry.
Yeah, it's all cherry.
This is an Italian terracotta.
It's not a terracotta.
Looks like Terracotta to me.
It looks like Terracotta.
Yeah.
Well, it used to be carpeted, but after 11 years and five dogs, the carpet came up.
Plus the carpet in here.
It's coming up for a long time.
Did you build this house?
I did.
I designed it and built it.
We built it in over the years, 86 and 87.
You were probably working on it.
I was in the process of designing it.
Yeah, exactly.
Yeah.
This is funny.
I remember doing a 180 turn, though, coming off the road.
I don't know why I remember the 180 turn coming to your place.
And if you need a bathroom, they're all right.
Okay, great.
Thanks.
And then this is where things happen.
Uh-huh.
The kitchen.
Nice.
That's where the dogs, I'm going to put the dogs out.
I was just going to do that.
I'm going to put them out and put the fence around so they can't get in the door.
Come on.
Let's go, guys.
Charlie will stay.
Do you work frenetically?
You say you get up at 4 o'clock in the morning?
4 to 6, yeah.
That's a good working time to you?
It's the best.
That time of the day, especially in wintertime, it's still dark out.
I know the phone's not going to ring.
And once the dogs are fed and got all the chores done, that's my time.

Beyond that, I mean, starting at 9 o'clock in the morning, the phone starts ringing, the help arrives, you know, I've got things to tend to, I've got activities I have to oversee and all that kind of stuff.
So the work gets a little bit jumbled after that.
And then it's work as work can, you know.
Steve, do you know pretty much what you're doing when you get up?
I mean, you do...
I had no, when I go to bed the night before, pretty much what I want to be doing the next day.
I mean, do you structure it?

I mean, you do engraving, you do illustrating, you do... No, yeah, it generally structures itself, the activities, and it depends on what I have to get done for, you know, to make the production schedule.
But I found lately that I was amused by a story I read about...
Morrison, the Nobel laureate, Ms.
Morrison.
Oh, it is Tony.
Tony Morrison.
She said that.
She was saying in an interview one time that she didn't have any rituals, that there were no rituals that she owed to or anything.
And further in the conversation with the interviewer, she said something about getting up every morning because she liked to welcome the day, liked to see the sun go up.
That's not a ritual.
Yeah, that's not a ritual.
Sure, it's a ritual.
But I've been noticing that, I mean, I certainly have always known I have rituals, but recently I've been noticing that the pattern.
See, in your reading this journal, you're going to see things that I don't see, because I feel it's a day-by-day thing, rather than a document.
One of these things, I'm going to sit down with it and actually look at it.
Do you mind if I shoot a couple pictures?
Oh, no, no.
But one of the things I'm noticing is that the first thing I do, after I get to my chore stuff, that's always the first thing,
But after the chores are done, I spend generally an hour to an hour and a half reading and writing.
Because I would read Newsweek every week from cover to cover, pretty much.
That's sort of my... They saw that in the journal, though.
Why Newsweek in particular?
No particular reason, except that Newsweek in 1982 did a nice article about my Alice.
So you're loyal.
They were loyal, yes.
Time magazine calls up and says...
you know, would you get a subscription to Time Magazine?
I said, no, I subscribed to Newsweek.
And they said, well, why don't you subscribe to Time?
I said, because Newweek's done two articles.
I mean, Time's never done one.
I said, and this guy who's calling you is a telemarketer.
He doesn't have a clue.
You figure you're another guy giving him a hard time, right?
Yeah, but it shuts him up.
Oh, okay.
So I read the paper, and generally that's all done sitting on the property, you know, and that's my reading time.
And then,
I go in and I pull up the journal.
I always write the journal the day after.
It's a reflection on the day before, but I write it in the tenths of the day before.
And that way I find that it cuts a lot of the chaff out.
If I do it the day of, I put too many things in, I think sometimes.
And then I answer my email, write letters.
You like email, huh?
I do.
I can tell.
I'm sorry.
Because you're fast.
Even the one I sent you last night, I do statuses.
And you read that within eight minutes of it being sent.
So I said, the little things I picked up, you know.
I'm that way.
I make at least three sweeps a day to see that.
I love it.
Well, I pay $19 for my service.
It doesn't matter how long I stay on, it's the same amount of money.
You know, my daughter, she's upstairs.
Hers is $4 a month.
She has to pay for every time she goes on.
Oh, that's not so big.
You know, and it's wonderful.
It's there.
It's in writing.
You can choose to print it out or not, you know.
That's very interesting.
Here you are, a man of the book, and yet you certainly are adapting.
What's the word I'm looking for?
You seem to be making the transition without any... I resisted it.
...to electronic... Five years ago, I would have said I'll never get involved with computers.
I was not only a cyber-phobe, but a cyber-clasp.
And I had nothing good to say about them.
And then I started, you know, I just see what can be done in people writing, and I like to write.
I mean, I really do like to write, but I've never written because, for me, writing is, as I have found out, writing is a process of revision and revision and revision and revision.
And when you write calligraphically, revisions are a pain in the ass, especially if you, you know, it looks pretty
It looks real nice down the page.
You don't want to go scratching things out, you know.
And then typing, I've never learned how to type properly.
And I would be in a fit of inspiration or whatever, writing, and I'd hear the bell go off for the carriage return.
Then I would, of course, ignore it.
Figuring I'd get this one more word in there, but then I'd forget that I hadn't.
And everything's going in that one spot, you know.
And then you have a really great idea, but you've got to put another sheet of paper in.
I love my manual.
I have four or five manual typewriters.
I love them.
But you can type, and you've been doing that.
It's part of your life.
I'm actually terrific.
Have you always kept a journal?
No, I've kept a day book since the mid-70s.
But the day book was just a, I did this today sort of thing.
When I was doing The Wizard of Oz, I did a journal for about 45 days, which was a little bit more expanded than what I did in a day book.
But when I started with the Bible, I decided that being inspired by Jean Cocteau's Diary of Making Beauty and the Beast, which I had my students read, those who will,
And I loved his journal of that because he dealt with some of the poetic issues, some of the creative issues of making that film.
But the thing that impressed me so much was his attention to, or his talking about the mundane things.
The actor that gets a car buckle on his ass and can't sit in the saddle.
the Luftwaffe flying over and having to shut the sound down, the failure of electricity, you know, all of these things.
That really is what impresses me and why I want my students to read it is because this is what the life is about.
It's that day-to-day stuff, and I just decided when I started this project that I would do a detailed journal.
I mean, because it was the Bible.
Yeah, I figured this is going to be the biggest thing I ever do, and I want a real good record of what I did.
And a journal also serves as a legal document, especially if you've got a hard copy someplace that you can verify that the document you have in your computer hasn't been changed.
You can't go in and say that you were someplace or did something.
Like, I have my calendar.
I can go back and change it.
Well, and sometimes you do.
Sure.
You know, I go looking at my trip to Italy.
Well, I went to a few places that I didn't have in there.
And I certainly want you to put that back in.
And I've got proof that I was at these places, but I sure want the calendar to indicate that I was there.
Well, I do the same thing, but I have two copies.
I have a copy of a journal that I feel perfectly free going in and changing around.
But I also have the one that's pristine.
And I copy that off about every month, every two months, and send it to Bruce Kovner, who's my partner.
And so he had a hard copy of it, unedited.
But that demonstrates, that documents the fact that... It documents everything, yeah, absolutely.
When bills get paid, you know, what discussions I had with so-and-so and what we agreed to and so on.
Now, of course, doing something like that, when you say, I had a discussion with so-and-so and we agreed to this, that is, of course,
not a legally binding thing, it's just my recollection of the conversation.
But at least it records my recollection of that conversation.
Again, I haven't got a chance to read, obviously read the whole journal, but there's a Bible project that you have been always... Oh, Nick, I have wanted to do this thing for 30 years.
It literally was that which came to me when I first started setting tight my hands.
Which was in 1969, 68, 69.
And the thing is that when you start studying typography and learning how to set the type and all that sort of thing, you're looking at the historic models.
And what are the great models?
The great models are Bibles.
So I'm seeing the Bruce Rogers Bible, the World Bible.
I'm seeing the Gutenbergs and the, you know, all of them.
And then I'm thinking, wouldn't it be great to do this?
And also to illustrate it.
And so, yeah, it's been on my mind.
In fact, I think it was 1977, March of 77, there was a symposium on illustration or on the book arts or something up at Leverett, the Leverett Arts and Crafts Center.
And David Bourbeau, myself, Fritz Eikenberg, and I think there was a fourth person, I can't remember who it was.
We're on this panel, and we were taking questions from the audience, and somebody said, addressed this question to all four of us.
If you had any project that you'd like to do, what would it be?
Eichenberg and I answered simultaneously and first, and both of us said the Bible.
Yes, I've been wanting to do this for a very long time.
Doing it at every level.
It's not just doing the illustrations.
Right.
So this is really your Bible, I would say.
It is.
Well, mine in one sense.
But then again, I was just writing this morning about the book art's more akin to theater and architecture and filmmaking than the art of painting or sculpture or performance art.
Because it's all a matter of teamwork.
I mean, I can't do this thing by myself.
I can do certain aspects of it by myself, but I certainly can't.
do the whole of it, because I'm not a paper maker, I'm not a typographer, I'm not a punch cutter or a type designer, all that sort of thing.
It depends on so many people.
And the least of all of that is not someone to pay the bill.
In fact, it's one of the reasons I think the thing hasn't been done before, because it's too bloody expensive.
It's costing $2 million to do this project.
We've already spent 1.73 minutes.
So you figure, I mean, just the bindings alone are nearly $2,000 a book.
Why don't you describe some of these?
Well, I was hoping I'd have one here today, but it wasn't finished.
And I was going to drive down to East Hampton and bring it up.
This is just the New Testament, but the binding of the finished Bible is going to be similar to this, except instead of the handmade paper over Lent boards.
It's full vellum.
Over what kind of boards?
Over thin boards.
What kind of words do you use?
Limp.
Limp.
Just so I don't have to label over that.
L-I-N-P, limp.
Yeah, limp vellum, which is an ancient means or way of binding books.
There's no glue in it anywhere.
It's a complete non-adhesive binding.
So, I mean, it's a little more finished than this, but... But this is vellum?
This is genuine?
No, this is paper.
This is handmade paper.
And the finished product is genuine vellum.
We have to kill two goats for every Bible.
That's the way it is.
I'm sorry about that.
You know what you're going to do?
There's sort of a...
There's something biblical about that anyway.
If there's any translation, I think it took 250 for each Gutenberg Bible.
Exactly.
Are you amazed that I know that?
No, I'm not at all.
I'm amazed.
They used to refer to prayer books and Bibles in terms of flocks.
This is a two-flock Bible or this is a three-flock Bible.
Where did I get that?
I don't know where I came up with that.
Well, it is a detail that somebody gave me, and I don't know where it came from, but I don't make things like that up.
I'm not smart enough to make a thing like that up.
I might just quote you why.
Yeah, but I mean, it's like, how many flocks of goats are we going to have to kill to do this thing?
I don't know how many goats comprise a flock, you know?
Maybe there are 30 goats to a flock.
I don't know.
But this is going to be a mini flock binding.
So are all the engravings done?
It will be done by next week, I think, or a week after.
I guess six more to do.
Five more.
Can you show me at some point, show me a little bit what you do?
Almost all of them.
Oh, yeah, I can show you exactly what I'm doing.
That would be nice if we could have a little... I'm engraving... Today I started engraving... I finished this morning, mid-morning.
I finished an engraving I started the day before yesterday, which was Moses and his sepulcher.
which is the next to the last or last image of the Pentateuch.
And then I picked up right after that, within 45 minutes, I picked up the next block that I wanted to do, which is the coming storm, the coming deluge.
Not Noah, but Noah and Noah's two sons and two cats on board here.
Do you know the word cat does not appear in the Bible anywhere?
No.
It's not there.
And I did a book a few years ago.
What's the word in existence?
Do you know?
Do we know?
Yeah, it just doesn't appear.
A lion appears, and a dog appears, and all that stuff.
But the word cat does not appear in the English Bible.

So that little fact, coupled up with my having done a number of years ago a children's book called Noah's Cats and the Devil's Fire, which is aI've forgotten what the nationality is, but it's an Eastern European origin.
And it's a legend that the devil got on board the ark in the form of a mouse, in the form of a rat, and the two cats basically kick his ass off.
But in so doing, the devil retains and invades the cat's spirit in some ways, and it makes their eyes sparkle, and that's why their eyes glow at night.
That's great.
Yeah, it's a very nice look.
You're choosing, you're making the decision on what scenes to illustrate?
How are you doing that?
Is it more or less the way the text is progressing and we need an illustration here?
That's exactly right.
It's spatial more than anything.
Really?
Yeah.
When I did it, well, it's a long time ago now, it seems.
It would have been three years ago.
I bought the largest paperback Bible I could find.
It happened to be a new translation at that time.
I had previously gone through...
I don't know how many monographs on the work of Rembrandt, Mantegna, Velazquez, you know, all of my favorites, the Dores even, and made up lists of illustrations of things that interest me.

Now, if it were something that didn't interest me, I didn't make a note of it, but I made up this list and then I would see where Rembrandt did the same thing, Potiphar's wife, and then you would see another image of Potiphar's wife and then another one.
So I think, hmm, that's probably something that I should investigate.
So I made up, from that I deduced, or derived, I derived a final list of illustrations, which is, I think, about 300 potential images long.
About 300.
For both the new and the old?
New and old, yeah.
150 each, about 100.
Well, the New Testament's only a fifth of the whole.
So the New Testament has, I think, 57 or 58 images in it.
And then each one of the other four sections has roughly 50.
So again, so you're reading the Bible.
Have you had to reread the whole Bible?
I haven't reread the whole thing, no, but I have certainly reread a lot of the sections.
And of course, there are some parts of it that I've read over and over and over.
Ecclesiastes, Proverbs.
And how do you pick a scene beyond the spatial element?
Well, see, let me finish this other thing.
So I took that list of illustrations, and I took this newly bought paperback Bible,
I put a sticky, a yellow sticky, so that it protruded in front of the fore edge of the book by about a quarter of an inch and staggered them so they'd be like tabs in a loose-leaf binder.
Then I just took that Bible and studied the edge of it.
That way I could see where it needed something and where it was all jammed up.
is totally jammed up, because you've got some of the greatest stories in Genesis, I mean, from the... I don't know what you mean, where it was jammed up in Genesis.
There were 15 illustrations in five pages.
Too many stickies in that area.
But in other areas, like, say, for instance, Ecclesiastes and Proverbs, there were none.
Because Rembrandt didn't do illustrations for Ecclesiastes, Proverbs, the Psalms, the Song of Psalms.
Or Job.
I think he made them joke.
Dor did some things for Joe, but he didn't do any for the other books of the poetry.
And the books of poetry were left wanting.
So then I had to go back through and pull stickies out where there were too many, where it was too compact with illustrations.
And then go in where it was too lean.
I'll put it that way.
Go into the places where it was too fat with illustrations and take things out.
And then go into places where the stickies told me that my scheme, my plan was too lean and put stickies in.
And where I had to put stickies in is where I really had to do the reading.
You know, I really had to find out what was going on there.
Yes?
I should have had that on the table.
The American Bible Society Auditor.
Yeah.
And what are these retailing for?
Ten grand.
How many?
Four hundred.
So they're also getting Andrews.
I don't care if they get Andrews nor they get mine.
How many are subscribed at this point?
At this point, what do we have?
Four or four?
Fifty?
That we have.
And we're only going to sell a hundred copies ourselves.
Heritage is going to sell the other three hundred.
That's why you were reading.
That's why I was reading.
Heritage.
Yeah, yeah.
But I remembered when I read the book, when did it come out, two years ago?
Boy, is it.
Oh, shit, don't tell me that.
Oh, God.
What did it win?
You up for the Pulitzer?
No, thank you.
National?
I was a finalist for the National Book Critics.
Okay, all right.
Which is not bad.
I'd say not.
I was trying to remember that the other day and I couldn't.
Four years ago.
Yeah, 95.
And it's been selling very well.
I've never seen it before, but I've argued that other people have done it long before me.
In the form of a self-interview.
and where I have a queue.
They have that in the journal.
I've seen that.
Yeah.
It's just a more interesting way for me to write about things than a simple academic discourse.
So you're responding to questions.
Yeah.
So I pretend I'm two people and I realize it's my image.
So Mariani wrote the introduction for the same image and he's talking about thebecause that's all they did.
They did my self-interviews about the crucifixion.
And so Mariani had deduced that the muse is a big black woman.
And I don't know where the hell he got that, but I had figured out a long time ago it was a woman.
But he figures it was a black woman I knew when I was a kid.
And I dearly loved her.
So this started in 95, I guess.
Yeah, August 25, 1995.
And I pit into that date because it was that date that Bruce Covner called me and said he'd finance it.
So the big stumbling block then was the money.
Basically there were...
three stumbling blocks.
The first stumbling block was money, just to be able to do it.
I used the term today that I was writing in the journal, architectural economics we're talking about.
Because you can build buildings for the kind of money we're talking about.
That's for sure.
That's the first stumbling block.
The second stumbling block was that, and I think that I'm the culprit in this, but there aren't any engraving blocks in the market, wood engraving blocks.
The last blocks that I bought were so bad that they looked beautiful to the feel, to the touch, but boy, when you start cutting, they were awful.
And they're frankly expensive, something like 20 pounds a square inch or something like that.
I mean, it's like, phew.
But these last indefinitely, right?
Yeah, but still and all, the wood isn't good.
It can't get to the size I need.
Is it also that people don't know that this is a lost art?
Do you think this is a dying art?
Yes and no.
I think that the quality of the materials has diminished, but I think it's also that people who start cutting this wood, who learn on this wood, won't notice.
You know, they'll fall right into it.
But if you know the good stuff and then you come to the second, you know, lower grade stuff, it's too much of a shock.
So what did you learn on it?
I learned really good boxwood.
You know, really good boxwood.
And so now, I mean, I'd rather cut maple than the kind of boxwood I've been, than the last boxwood that I bought.
And where have you been getting this boxwood?
England.
England.
Yeah.
And at the best sources.
So anyway,
discovered through Kim Marker.
You know Kim Marker at the University of Iowa?
Yeah.
His is the Stonewall Press and, Jesus, you'll have to memo me on this one.
He's one of the great printers in America, and he's pretty much responsible for the Center for the Book at the University of Iowa.
And he had sent me a tiny little piece of this plastic stuff with a note saying, I understand you can engrave this stuff.
I looked at it and I said, horse shit, that's plastic, you can't do that.
And I carried this little gray piece of plastic around with me when I'd go around doing talks and people would inevitably ask, why aren't you engraving anymore?
Well, there's no wood.
Well, isn't there something else you can use?
Reach down in the pocket and pull this little piece of stuff out and say, yeah,
Ken Merker tells me I can engrave on this stuff, but it's plastic, and that's crap, and I won't do it.
And so I said, that was three or four or five years I did that.
And I was out in Pasadena at the Art Center School doing a workshop.
Same situation exactly, except this time when I answered the question, I had an engraving tool in my hand, and I went, cut across the surface of this stuff.
It was so sweet.
Oh, it was so sweet.
You hadn't tried it before.
Never tried it.
It just looked ugly.
And it was awful gray kind of stuff.
It looked like... So what happened?
You were actually trying to demonstrate how lousy it was, and you did it.
And so what did you say?
And I said, you guys hold on a minute.
I'll be right back to you here.
Hold on just a sec.
And I made five or six more cuts to make sure I wasn't imagining it.
And I said, holy mother.
So I made a little drawing on the block.
and actually did some engraving, drew a little dog's head or something, and I started doing something.
Man, it held that line nicely.
So I got in touch with the guy and invented it.
Now, imagine this.
This guy has a wonderfully double ironic name, or a name of a double irony.
His name is Richard Woodman, and he lives in Redwood City, California.
That's great.
He's an Englishman who was an engineer.
He retired a number of years ago and decided in his retirement he was going to go back to his childhood hobby, which was wood engraving.
And he found out what we already know, which is there than any wood.
But being a chemical engineer, he decided to invent a substitute.
So he invented this stuff called Resingrave.
What do you call it?
Resingrave?
Resingrave.
R-E-S-I-N-G-R-A-V-E.
It's a cast polymer resin.
That must be a capital I. There must be a zero on the swing.
Exactly.
Yeah.
Specifically for artists like yourself.
Yeah, exactly.
But nobody would bite on the stuff much.
It was a hard sell.
Rembrandt Graphics was carrying it, but he insisted on toning the surface of this block with some sort of an Indian ink wash.
So I called him up and talked to him.
I said, hey, listen, could you make some blocks for me, but don't tone them?
Can you leave the material white?
And he said, sure.
So he started making these things for me, and we've gone back and forth on, you know, trying to get them manufactured a little flatter and type high and all that sort of thing.
It's not perfect, but man, I tell you, it sure made this project possible.
So you used these blocks for this?
Yeah, absolutely.
So these aren't wood blocks?
These aren't wooden engravings.
Now these are, oh, sorry, that was the book opening.
These are done on plastic.
I mean, and there's nobody, Nick, there's absolutely nobody can tell the difference between this and the wood engraving.
I mean, I couldn't tell the difference.
What would they look for to say it's not a win-win?
The edges of the white lines would scallop.
They would be fuzzy instead of really clean.
But if the tools are properly sharp, it doesn't leave that scalloped edge.
It's marked.
The other thing is that with the... Hey, Dan.
Dan, this is Nick.
Nick, this is Dan.
Hey, Nick.
How you doing?
There are no images that have any big white areas.
